thread.title: VCs aim for the stars as 'frontier tech' gains traction
thread.title_full: VCs aim for the stars as 'frontier tech' gains traction | Business Spectator

author: Krishan Sharma
title: VCs aim for the stars as 'frontier tech' gains traction
text:
Start-ups exploring drones, space, augmented reality and virtual reality might be the key instigators of the next wave of innovation if the latest activity by key venture capitalists is anything to go by.
The so-called “frontier technology” start-ups have already collectively raised $US2.17 billion ($3.14bn) in the first half of 2015, more than double the amount of capital invested in emerging technology during the whole of 2014, according to a report by venture capital research firm CB Insights.
Google, Qualcomm and Intel, through their corporate and venture arms, rank as three of the most active investors in the frontier tech industry. One of the biggest venture bets was the $US1.19bn funding of Elon Musk’s SpaceX made at the beginning of the year by Google and Rothenberg Ventures.
The internet search giant has been plugged into the scene for a while, starting its investment spree following a half-a-billion-dollar acquisition of satellite start-up Skybox Imaging last year. Since then it has invested in drone start-ups Airware and Skycatch; VR start-ups AltspaceVR and Magic Leap; and space start-ups Orbital Insight to name a few.
Smartphone chip maker Qualcomm is keen to adapt its Snapdragon processors for drones and has also made a push into this space by making investments in 3D Robotics and Skycatch.
Other strategic investments include movie studio Legendary Entertainment’s investment into the much-hyped Magic Leap AR platform — an investment that chief executive Thomas Tull believes has the potential to disrupt the entertainment landscape.
While SpaceX and its mission of launching reusable rockets to space has dominated overall funding, there are other well-funded VC-backed space start-ups within segments like satellite operations and imagery.
These include Planet Labs and Spire, which aim to rapidly capture images of Earth via satellites on a daily basis in addition to Orbital Insight and Windward, which use satellite imagery to derive unique insights about Earth to a wide range of industries ranging from maritime, wildlife conservation to weather.
Oneweb plans to put more than 600 satellites in space to enable global internet access and has raised a total of $US500 million. Kymeta has raised $US82m to help develop a new form of satellite antenna to connect to mobile networks and communication satellites.
It’s expected that more than 2000 nano-satellites will be launched by 2020 when the global satellite imagery market will be worth more than $US5bn.
While space-related start-ups might have raised the lion’s share of equity financing since 2014, there’s growing investor interest in drones or unmanned aerial vehicles, according to Michael Dempsey, who helped compile CB Insights’ report. “We’re starting to hear that every venture capitalist wants a drone investment,” he said.
Drone investment activity has picked up markedly over the past three quarters, reaching an all-time high in the second quarter of 2015, with $US109m invested on 16 deals. The funding was buoyed by the $US75m financing to DJI Innovations, the largest consumer drone manufacturer in the world.
